foundit66

John Burke, an atheist, and his wife, a pantheist, had left the line blank. As a result, the bureau denied the Burkes' application. After the couple began court action, however, the bureau changed its regulations, and the couple was able to adopt a baby boy from the Children's Aid and Adoption Society in East Orange. 
 
 Last year the Burkes presented their adopted son, David, now 31, with a baby sister, Eleanor Katherine, now 17 months, whom they acquired from the same East Orange agency. Since the agency endorsed the adoption, the required final approval by a judge was expected to be pro forma. Instead, Superior Court Judge William Camarata raised the religious issue. 
 
 Inestimable Privilege. In an extraordinary decision, Judge Camarata denied the Burkes' right to the child because of their lack of belief in a Supreme Being. Despite the Burkes' "high moral and ethical standards," he said, the New Jersey state constitution declares that "no person shall be deprived of the inestimable privilege of worshiping Almighty God in a manner agreeable to the dictates of his own conscience." Despite Eleanor Katherine's tender years, he continued, "the child should have the freedom to worship as she sees fit, and not be influenced by prospective parents who do not believe in a Supreme Being." 
 
 The Burkes are now living in Carterville, Ill., near Southern Illinois University, where John Burke has worked for the past year as a speech pathologist. Nevertheless, Judge Camarata ordered the parents to send David's sister back to the New Jersey adoption agency. Two weeks ago, aided by the American Civil Liberties Union, the Burkes appealed directly to the New Jersey Supreme Court, which agreed to hear the case. If they fail in their appeal, Eleanor Katherine may have to leave the only family she has ever known and await adoption by another couple whose religious convictions satisfy the State of New Jersey.
 Can Atheists Be Parents? - TIME
 
 I realize this is atypical, but I think it demonstrates a bigger reality in today's America.
 I've seen polls that state that Americans would sooner elect a gay man to office than an atheist.
 While some atheists put up a stink over ant-hill issues they insist are mountains ...
 ... there does exist a flip-side discrimination in America...
Matthew S
Didn't the judge see the irony in his decision? The last time I looked fundie parents brainwash their children and deny their children their right to believe as the wish.

 If the judge had the intellectual capacity to see the irony of his decision, he would never have had the impetus to make the decision.
 
 
The last time I looked fundie parents brainwash their children and deny their children their right to believe as the wish.

 What are the odds that this judge is one of said children?

Good grief. Whenever one thinks the depths of religious ignorance have been plumbed, some religious zealot goes a few fathoms further. Whatever next? Compulsory sterilisation of atheists?
jitobear
I highly question whether this decision is legal. It seems to fly in the face of the first ammendment to me - as well as anti-discrimination laws.

 Such times were so repressive and discriminatory for peace loving atheists everywhere.

 Fortunatly, us atheists are a subversive lot, more able to blend in to societies and cunningly manipulate the laws and customs to our own ends.
 Soon, our dark master, Satan, will appear to reward us for our unending endeavors...
 
 MuAhahahahhahaha...
 
 
 Or something like that.
 
 Although, in some recent civil proceedings, I wish I had the ability to state my lack of a belief in a deity more freely...rather than feel compelled to take up the mantle of moderate Catholic Christian...which, ironically is what the judge was...
 
 Can we say WIN!
 
 I knew we could.

My wife has always been spiritual but felt Christianity would be more proper for our child. So she started attending church and going to bible study. When my wife found out she was pregnant with triplets, in her joy she told the pastor of the church. His reply was... "Do you think it's wise to bring children in to this world, since you and your husband are not properly 'Yoked?'". She soon left the church and Christianity behind for the even handedness of spirituality.
Zardoz

 LOL, I've heard that one too.
 
 Often by pastors who really haven't read the passages of 1 Corinthinas in context to how a believing spouse is supposed to deal with an unbelieving partner according to the wisdom of the Apostle Paul.
 So, if any current pastor thinks he's greater than Paul, stone him. Stone him hard...from long range with little lead stones hurled at extremely high velostiy from an unmarked metalic device bought from some guy you met downtown on the corner.
 It's the biblical thing to do...although, Jesus would probably just curse him out. ;)
 
 I wonder why they think the faith of their followers is so weak with such comments. Are the pastors not training them properly that they must run and hide from imaginary threats. Can not your wife sanctify your children and with complacent support from you, raise them in the Church or as Christians?
 
 I was a very supportive husband of my wife's and kid's faith with only the youngest not becoming indoctrinated into the system but, in time he could have.
 It wasn't a single thing I did that eventually caused most to renounce their beliefs. It was entirely the actions of their fellow Christians, their church leaders and how they eventually viewed themselves in context of their supposed bliefs that they eventually saw as hypocritical that caused most to break away from fundamentalism.

 I think that any atheist who brings up a child in complete ignorance of the dominant religion(s) of his home country is doing it a disservice. Much in Western civilisation, in history and literature, is based on the bible, and complete ignorance of the bible as a work of literature at least is an important deficit.
 
 Still, in trying to teach the child of an atheist about religion, you probably need to be pretty careful about the teacher, or how the program is structured. One can't just throw them into any old Sunday school and hope for the best.
Zardoz

I think that any atheist who brings up a child in complete ignorance of the dominant religion(s) of his home country is doing it a disservice.  Still, in trying to teach the child of an atheist about religion, you probably need to be pretty careful about the teacher, or how the program is structured. One can't just throw them into any old Sunday school and hope for the best.

 
 While I nominally agree, I find that in America a child raised by an atheist is about as ignorant of the dominant faiths as the followers of that faith are.
 
 Typical American Christian:
 'Ummm...Jesus, God, prayer, church...oh, BIBLE too...which I don't read. Um, does Christmas and Easter count? I like getting stuff.'
 Some may say 'Communion' or 'Holy Spirit' too.
 
 Toss on the profound revelations from the Simpsons and South Park on religion and you've pretty much summed up the religious education of most.
 Beyond that, you really don't need to know much of anything. Simply keep your mouth shut and blend in, fake it. Like everyone else is doing.
 
 Pushing a kid into Sunday school will reult in coloring papers or a really cultic brainwashing attempt.
 
 I've found that simply walking down the street and talking about religious signs and bumper stickers in lawns and on cars to be more religiously informative for my son.
 Dealing with issues from the 10 commandments to abortion and then the many tangents that arise. But, all that is really unnecessary and goes beyond what his peers learn and know.

 I haven't known many children of atheists, frankly, so I find it hard to generalise. I'm not really suggesting that atheists should bring up their children to understand all the arcane ins and outs of particular theologies -- who really cares about the "Assumption of the Virgin Mary" except some Catholics? And not even all of those. But I do think they need to read at least the common bits of the bible at least once in their lives, otherwise many literary allusions in English will escape them.
 
 Also, they won't understand Christian culture which they will grow up surrounded in, and it's probably wise not to rely on the religious erudition of the children of Christians which is where the child of an atheist would get most of their information from otherwise. There are undoubtedly many different ways of passing on such knowledge. One thing I'd try to ensure is they get a modicum of grounding in more than one religion, and not just the Western ones.
Zardoz

 I agree.
 I've actually had to speak to some counselors on this in dealing with my son.
 Had to remind them that morality and ethics aren't always found in just one book and had to illustrate object lessons I've engaged in. Such as returning 200 dollars the son found on the floor to it's rightful owner based on seeking empathy and understanding if the roles were reversed for him.
 
 My son probably has about as much understanding of other faiths (was just discussing the FLDS with him recently) that are common to the world or sensationalized in the media, as your average mono-religist has of their own faith. And he probably knows more about Christianity that most of his peers.
 
 I have stated that if we lived in an Islamic country, then those sects would be what he knew the most about.
 
 And, if he wants to embrace a religion on his own, he's fine to do so. So long as it's not excessively anti-social and criminal. Don't think I'd take kindly to the boy wanting to sacrifice virgins so he can get magical powers.
 
 I know a few children of 'athiests' and they all have different approaches.
 The ones who pretty much ignore religious issues altogether with their kids aren't much worse off than the believer who simply forces the kids to go to church on high holy days and ignores the faith the rest of the year.
 The only problems I've seen would be from the pushy evangelical kids who think they know it all and cause a commotion with their mandatory confrontations. Either there'll be friction or if the evangelical is friendly and charismatic, may lure the other kid to a church service. In the vast majority of cases, there's really not much to fear.
 A self rightious Jesus Freak can be just as annoying as a gothy-I-wear-all-black-and-am-always-moody kid.
 They'll either grow out of it or grow up and no longer be your problem.
